column4: apt-cache policy show me the current and previous version of a package. is there a way to go back to that older version?
sudo apt-get install PACKAGE=VERSION
the package seem to be a metapackage and only the metapackage seem to get downgraded. do you know if there is a way to resolve that as well?
nope
(I don't know, there may be a way)
well, i try to find the depends and see if apt will be kind to me
you can disable if you disable the dialog grabbing focus somewhere in gconf-editor
I don't want to disable the grabbing (which is a security feature). only the fade.
https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/gksu/+bug/43148 (see comments on hacking the code)
xorg.conf?
only one screen section in there

and everything in xorg.conf looks a bit off. no specifics is in it - only "Configured Video Device", "Configured Monitor" etc. not even a driver is specified - is that normal for the new xorg version?
yeah
create a xorg.conf and make sure it knows you only have one screen
hotplug is messing up I guess
ok. will do. is -phigh recommended?
sure, try with that first
-phigh created the exact same copy of xorg.conf. trying the normal way now.
k, resort to writing your own if you have to
also /var/log/Xorg.0.log may give some hints about what Xorg is thingk
dpkg-reconfigure only let me specify keyboard. i never get the gpu driver option nor the monitor one... strange
k, I would just write an xorg.conf then
Xorg.0.log is a text-book success story. oh well... need to get my hands dirty it seems.
